instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01958: What is 820-01958? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.P5VG3S_EN: What is P5VG3S_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_G3S power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V
threads.message: I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, no obvious liquid damage that is stuck at 5V and 0.25A. After 10 seconds meter goes black and reboots to 5V. PPBUS is 12.31V, I have 3.3, 1.8 and 1.1v. None of the <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> is getting hot or looks bad. Should I try replace or something else to try first?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V
threads.message:
If USB meter restart, means the board try to start and probably SMC detects a fault and restart power on sequence.
Check for short on all secondary power supplies.

If you connect the battery, USB ports switch to 20V?

Just in case, try DFU revive.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V
threads.message: Tried DFU already didnt work, battery is the same 5V. Will check for shorts more thoroughly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V
threads.message: So no shorts on all powerlines. I have the 3.3, 1.1 and 0.82v voltages. Looks like CPU is not turning on. When i check <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> power in, I get 12.3v on VIN and 0V on VCC 5V. Should 5V be present here prior to boot, I assume yes? No short on these lines though. <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> gives 3.3v no 5V. Do these boards work in the same way as the old ones and I need EN and SLP signals from CPU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V
threads.message:
PCH/CPU not involved yet, until G3S and SSD voltages appear.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power on sequence available, should serve for <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> too.

Do you note any pulse at <SIGNAL>P5VG3S_EN</SIGNAL>?

Any fault history available?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V
threads.message: no fault history and board looks new. I dont get any pulse on EN

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V
threads.message: T2 and <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> are the suspects here.
